Bissonette, J.A., D.J. Harrison, C.D. Hargis, T.G. Chapin. 1997. The influence of spatial scale and scale-sensitive properties on habitat selection by American marten. In: Bissonette JA (ed) Wildlife and landscape ecology. Springer, New York, pp 368–385.

Chapin, T.G., D.J. Harrison, and D.M. Phillips. 1997. Seasonal habitat selection by marten in an untrapped forest preserve. The Journal of Wildlife Management, 61(3):707-717.
habitat_description:
Martes Americana inhabits mature, mesic forests, with large diameter trees, high canopy cover, and a complex understory and groundcover structure (Burnett, 1981; Clark et al., 1987; Ruggiero et al., 1994; Chapin et al. 1997; Kirk and Zielinski, 2009). Martens avoid open areas, grasslands, and clearcuts (Clark et al., 1987).

Those west of the Great Plains are found almost exclusively in coniferous forest (Clark et al., 1987; Buskirk et al., 1989; Ruggiero et al., 1994), though occasionally in mixed forests with aspen, birch, and/or cottonwood (Kirk and Zielinski, 2009; Stone, 2010). These western populations avoid xeric sites and ponderosa pine, douglas-fir, juniper, and pinyon woodlands and forests (Buskirk et al., 1989; Buskirk and Ruggiero, 1994; Ruggiero et al., 1994; Stone, 2010).

In the Great Lakes region, the species prefers mature, large-diameter, upland, mesic hardwood forests and occasionally uses upland conifer or mixed forests (Wright, 1999; Dumyahn et al., 2007). Similarly, in New England and the maritime provinces, martens display no preference for coniferous forests, given high canopy cover and tree heights > 12 m (Chapin et al., 1997).
